Abstract

A kğ‘˜k-query Locally Decodable Code (LDC) encodes an nğ‘›n-bit message xğ‘¥x as an Nğ‘N-bit codeword Câ€‹(x),ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x), such that one can probabilistically recover any bit xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} of the message by querying only kğ‘˜k bits of the codeword Câ€‹(x)ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x), even after some constant fraction of codeword bits has been corrupted. The major goal of LDC related research is to establish the optimal trade-off between length and query complexity of such codes.

RecentlyÂ [34] introduced a novel technique for constructing locally decodable codes and vastly improved the upper bounds for code length. The technique is based on Mersenne primes. In this paper we extend the work ofÂ [34] and argue that further progress via these methods is tied to progress on an old number theory question regarding the size of the largest prime factors of Mersenne numbers.

Specifically, we show that every Mersenne number m=2tâˆ’1ğ‘šsuperscript2ğ‘¡1m=2^{t}-1 that has a prime factor p>mÎ³ğ‘superscriptğ‘šğ›¾p>m^{\gamma} yields a family of kâ€‹(Î³)ğ‘˜ğ›¾k(\gamma)-query locally decodable codes of length expâ¡(n1/t).superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡\exp\left(n^{1/t}\right). Conversely, if for some fixed kğ‘˜k and all Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 one can use the technique ofÂ [34] to obtain a family of kğ‘˜k-query LDCs of length expâ¡(nÏµ);superscriptğ‘›italic-Ïµ\exp\left(n^{\epsilon}\right); then infinitely many Mersenne numbers have prime factors larger than known currently.

1 Introduction

Classical error-correcting codes allow one to encode an nğ‘›n-bit string xğ‘¥x into in Nğ‘N-bit codeword Câ€‹(x),ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x), in such a way that xğ‘¥x can still be recovered even if Câ€‹(x)ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x) gets corrupted in a number of coordinates. It is well-known that codewords Câ€‹(x)ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x) of length N=Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘›N=O(n) already suffice to correct errors in up to Î´â€‹Nğ›¿ğ‘\delta N locations of Câ€‹(x)ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x) for any constant Î´<1/4.ğ›¿14\delta<1/4. The disadvantage of classical error-correction is that one needs to consider all or most of the (corrupted) codeword to recover anything about x.ğ‘¥x. Now suppose that one is only interested in recovering one or a few bits of x.ğ‘¥x. In such case more efficient schemes are possible. Such schemes are known as locally decodable codes (LDCs). Locally decodable codes allow reconstruction of an arbitrary bit xi,subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}, from looking only at kğ‘˜k randomly chosen coordinates of Câ€‹(x),ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x), where kğ‘˜k can be as small as 2.22. Locally decodable codes have numerous applications in complexity theoryÂ [15, 29], cryptographyÂ [6, 11] and the theory of fault tolerant computationÂ [24]. Below is a slightly informal definition of LDCs:

A (k,Î´,Ïµ)ğ‘˜ğ›¿italic-Ïµ(k,\delta,\epsilon)-locally decodable code encodes nğ‘›n-bit strings to Nğ‘N-bit codewords Câ€‹(x),ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x), such that for every iâˆˆ[n],ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n], the bit xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} can be recovered with probability 1âˆ’Ïµ,1italic-Ïµ1-\epsilon, by a randomized decoding procedure that makes only kğ‘˜k queries, even if the codeword Câ€‹(x)ğ¶ğ‘¥C(x) is corrupted in up to Î´â€‹Nğ›¿ğ‘\delta N locations.

One should think of Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0 and Ïµ<1/2italic-Ïµ12\epsilon<1/2 as constants. The main parameters of interest in LDCs are the length Nğ‘N and the query complexity k.ğ‘˜k. Ideally we would like to have both of them as small as possible. The concept of locally decodable codes was explicitly discussed in various papers in the early 1990sÂ [2, 28, 21]. Katz and TrevisanÂ [15] were the first to provide a formal definition of LDCs. Further work on locally decodable codes includesÂ [3, 8, 20, 4, 16, 30, 34, 33, 14, 23].

Below is a brief summary of what was known regarding the length of LDCs prior toÂ [34]. The length of optimal 222-query LDCs was settled by Kerenidis and de Wolf inÂ [16] and is expâ¡(n).ğ‘›\exp(n).111Throughout the paper we use the standard notation expâ¡(x)=defeOâ€‹(x).superscriptdefğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‚ğ‘¥\exp(x)\mathbin{\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}}e^{O(x)}. The best upper bound for the length of 333-query LDCs was expâ¡(n1/2)superscriptğ‘›12\exp\left(n^{1/2}\right) due to Beimel et al.Â [3], and the best lower bound is Î©~â€‹(n2)~Î©superscriptğ‘›2\tilde{\Omega}(n^{2})Â [33]. For general (constant) kğ‘˜k the best upper bound was expâ¡(nOâ€‹(logâ¡logâ¡k/(kâ€‹logâ¡k)))superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ‘˜\exp\left(n^{O\left(\log\log k/(k\log k)\right)}\right) due to Beimel et al.Â [4] and the best lower bound is Î©~â€‹(n1+1/(âŒˆk/2âŒ‰âˆ’1))~Î©superscriptğ‘›11ğ‘˜21\tilde{\Omega}\left(n^{1+1/\left(\lceil k/2\rceil-1\right)}\right)Â [33].

The recent workÂ [34] improved the upper bounds to the extent that it changed the common perception of what may be achievableÂ [12, 11].Â [34] introduced a novel technique to construct codes from so-called nice subsets of finite fields and showed that every Mersenne prime p=2tâˆ’1ğ‘superscript2ğ‘¡1p=2^{t}-1 yields a family of 333-query LDCs of length expâ¡(n1/t).superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡\exp\left(n^{1/t}\right). Based on the largest known Mersenne primeÂ [9], this translates to a length of less than expâ¡(n10âˆ’7).superscriptğ‘›superscript107\exp\left(n^{10^{-7}}\right). Combined with the recursive construction fromÂ [4], this result yields vast improvements for all values of k>2.ğ‘˜2k>2. It has often been conjectured that the number of Mersenne primes is infinite. If indeed this conjecture holds,Â [34] gets three query locally decodable codes of length N=expâ¡(nOâ€‹(1logâ¡logâ¡n))ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘›N=\exp\left(n^{O\left(\frac{1}{\log\log n}\right)}\right) for infinitely many n.ğ‘›n. Finally, assuming that the conjecture of Lenstra, Pomerance and WagstaffÂ [31, 22, 32] regarding the density of Mersenne primes holds,Â [34] gets three query locally decodable codes of length N=expâ¡(nOâ€‹(1log1âˆ’Ïµâ¡logâ¡n))ğ‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscript1italic-Ïµğ‘›N=\exp\left(n^{O\left(\frac{1}{\log^{1-\epsilon}\log n}\right)}\right) for all n,ğ‘›n, for everyÂ Ïµ>0.italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0.

1.1 Our results

In this paper we address two natural questions left open byÂ [34]:

  1. 1.

    Are Mersenne primes necessary for the constructions ofÂ [34]?

  2. 2.

    Has the technique ofÂ [34] been pushed to its limits, or one can construct better codes through a more clever choice of nice subsets of finite fields?

We extend the work ofÂ [34] and answer both of the questions above. In what follows let Pâ€‹(m)ğ‘ƒğ‘šP(m) denote the largest prime factor of m.ğ‘šm. We show that one does not necessarily need to use Mersenne primes. It suffices to have Mersenne numbers with polynomially large prime factors. Specifically, every Mersenne number m=2tâˆ’1ğ‘šsuperscript2ğ‘¡1m=2^{t}-1 such that Pâ€‹(m)â‰¥mÎ³ğ‘ƒğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šğ›¾P(m)\geq m^{\gamma} yields a family of kâ€‹(Î³)ğ‘˜ğ›¾k(\gamma)-query locally decodable codes of length expâ¡(n1/t).superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡\exp\left(n^{1/t}\right). A partial converse also holds. Namely, if for some fixed kâ‰¥3ğ‘˜3k\geq 3 and all Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 one can use the technique ofÂ [34] to (unconditionally) obtain a family of kğ‘˜k-query LDCs of length expâ¡(nÏµ);superscriptğ‘›italic-Ïµ\exp\left(n^{\epsilon}\right); then for infinitely many tğ‘¡t we have

Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)â‰¥(t/2)1+1/(kâˆ’2).ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘¡211ğ‘˜2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(t/2)^{1+1/(k-2)}. (1)

The boundÂ (1) may seem quite weak in light of the widely accepted conjecture saying that the number of Mersenne primes is infinite. However (for any kâ‰¥3ğ‘˜3k\geq 3) this bound is substantially stronger than what is currently known unconditionally. Lower bounds for Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡1P(2^{t}-1) have received a considerable amount of attention in the number theory literatureÂ [25, 26, 10, 27, 19, 18]. The strongest result to date is due to StewartÂ [27]. It says that for all integers tğ‘¡t ignoring a set of asymptotic density zero, and for all functions Ïµâ€‹(t)>0italic-Ïµğ‘¡0\epsilon(t)>0 where Ïµâ€‹(t)italic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon(t) tends to zero monotonically and arbitrarily slowly:

Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)>Ïµâ€‹(t)â€‹tâ€‹(logâ¡t)2/logâ¡logâ¡t.ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡1italic-Ïµğ‘¡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘¡P(2^{t}-1)>\epsilon(t)t\left(\log t\right)^{2}/\log\log t. (2)

There are no better bounds known to hold for infinitely many values of t,ğ‘¡t, unless one is willing to accept some number theoretic conjecturesÂ [19, 18]. We hope that our work will further stimulate the interest in proving lower bounds for Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡1P(2^{t}-1) in the number theory community.

In summary, we show that one may be able to improve the unconditional bounds ofÂ [34] (say, by discovering a new Mersenne number with a very large prime factor) using the same technique. However any attempts to reach the expâ¡(nÏµ)superscriptğ‘›italic-Ïµ\exp\left(n^{\epsilon}\right) length for some fixed query complexity and all Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 require either progress on an old number theory problem or some radically new ideas.

In this paper we deal only with binary codes for the sake of clarity of presentation. We remark however that our results as well as the results ofÂ [34] can be easily generalized to larger alphabets. Such generalization will be discussed in detail inÂ [35].

1.2 Outline

In sectionÂ 3 we introduce the key concepts ofÂ [34], namely that of combinatorial and algebraic niceness of subsets of finite fields. We also briefly review the construction of locally decodable codes from nice subsets. In sectionÂ 4 we show how Mersenne numbers with large prime factors yield nice subsets of prime fields. In sectionÂ 5 we prove a partial converse. Namely, we show that every finite field ğ”½qsubscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathbb{F}_{q} containing a sufficiently nice subset, is an extension of a prime field ğ”½p,subscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathbb{F}_{p}, where pğ‘p is a large prime factor of a large Mersenne number. Our main results are summarized in sectionsÂ 4.3 andÂ 5.4.

4.2 A sufficient condition for the existence of kğ‘˜k pğ‘p-th roots of unity summing to zero

Our argument in this section comes in three steps. First we briefly review the notion of (additive) Fourier coefficients of subsets of ğ”½2t.subscriptğ”½superscript2ğ‘¡\mathbb{F}_{2^{t}}. 4.3 Summary

In this section we summarize our positive results and show that one does not necessarily need to use Mersenne primes to construct locally decodable codes via the methods ofÂ [34]. It suffices to have Mersenne numbers with polynomially large prime factors. Recall that Pâ€‹(m)ğ‘ƒğ‘šP(m) denotes the largest prime factor of an integer m.ğ‘šm. 5 Nice subsets of finite fields yield Mersenne numbers with large prime factors

Definition 16

We say that a sequence {SiâŠ†ğ”½qiâˆ—}iâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ”½subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1\left\{S_{i}\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q_{i}}^{*}\right\}_{i\geq 1} of subsets of finite fields is kğ‘˜k-nice if every Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} is kğ‘˜k algebraically nice and tâ€‹(i)ğ‘¡ğ‘–t(i) combinatorially nice, for some integer valued monotonically increasing function t.ğ‘¡t.

The core propositionÂ 5 asserts that a subset SâŠ†ğ”½qâˆ—ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ”½ğ‘S\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*} that is kğ‘˜k algebraically nice and tğ‘¡t combinatorially nice yields a family of kğ‘˜k-query locally decodable codes of length expâ¡(n1/t).superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡\exp(n^{1/t}). Clearly, to get kğ‘˜k-query LDCs of length expâ¡(nÏµ)superscriptğ‘›italic-Ïµ\exp(n^{\epsilon}) for some fixed kğ‘˜k and every Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 via this proposition, one needs to exhibit a kğ‘˜k-nice sequence. In this section we show how the existence of a kğ‘˜k-nice sequence implies that infinitely many Mersenne numbers have large prime factors. Our argument proceeds in two steps. First we show that a kğ‘˜k-nice sequence yields an infinite sequence of primes {pi}iâ‰¥1,subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–1\left\{p_{i}\right\}_{i\geq 1}, where every Cpisubscriptğ¶subscriptğ‘ğ‘–C_{p_{i}} contains a kğ‘˜k-tuple of elements summing to zero. Next we show that Cpsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{p} contains a short additive dependence only if pğ‘p is a large factor of a Mersenne number.

5.1 A nice sequence yields infinitely many primes pğ‘p with short dependencies between pğ‘p-th roots of unity

5.4 Summary

In the beginning of this sectionÂ 5 we argued that in order to use the method ofÂ [34], (i.e., propositionÂ 5) to obtain kğ‘˜k-query locally decodable codes of length expâ¡(nÏµ)superscriptğ‘›italic-Ïµ\exp(n^{\epsilon}) for some fixed kğ‘˜k and all Ïµ>0,italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, one needs to exhibit a kğ‘˜k-nice sequence of subsets of finite fields. In what follows we use technical results of the previous subsections to show that the existence of a kğ‘˜k-nice sequence implies that infinitely many Mersenne numbers have large prime factors.

Theorem 24

Let kğ‘˜k be odd. Suppose there exists a kğ‘˜k-nice sequence of subsets of finite fields; then for infinitely many values of tğ‘¡t we have

Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)â‰¥(t/2)1+1/(kâˆ’2).ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘¡211ğ‘˜2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(t/2)^{1+1/(k-2)}. (40)

  • Proof:Â Â  Using lemmasÂ 21 andÂ 22 we conclude that a kğ‘˜k-nice sequence yields infinitely many primes pğ‘p such that ord2â€‹(p)â‰¤2â€‹p1âˆ’1/(kâˆ’1).subscriptord2ğ‘2superscriptğ‘11ğ‘˜1\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p)\leq 2p^{1-1/(k-1)}. Let pğ‘p be such a prime and t=ord2â€‹(p).ğ‘¡subscriptord2ğ‘t=\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p). Then Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)â‰¥(t/2)1+1/(kâˆ’2).ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘¡211ğ‘˜2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(t/2)^{1+1/(k-2)}. A combination of lemmasÂ 21 andÂ 23 yields a slightly stronger bound for the special case of 333-nice sequences.

Theorem 25

Suppose there exists a 333-nice sequence of subsets; then for infinitely many values of tğ‘¡t we have

Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)â‰¥(3/4)â€‹t2.ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡134superscriptğ‘¡2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(3/4)t^{2}. (41)

We would like to remind the reader that although the lower bounds for Pâ€‹(2tâˆ’1)ğ‘ƒsuperscript2ğ‘¡1P(2^{t}-1) given byÂ (40) andÂ (41) are extremely weak light of the widely accepted conjecture saying that the number of Mersenne primes is infinite, they are substantially stronger than what is currently known unconditionallyÂ (2).

6 Conclusion

RecentlyÂ [34] came up with a novel technique for constructing locally decodable codes and obtained vast improvements upon the earlier work. The construction proceeds in two steps. FirstÂ [34] shows that if there exist subsets of finite fields with certain â€™niceâ€™ properties then there exist good codes. NextÂ [34] constructs nice subsets of prime fields ğ”½psubscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathbb{F}_{p} for Mersenne primes pğ‘p.

In this paper we have undertaken an in-depth study of nice subsets of general finite fields. We have shown that constructing nice subsets is closely related to proving lower bounds on the size of largest prime factors of Mersenne numbers. Specifically we extended the constructions ofÂ [34] to obtain nice subsets of prime fields ğ”½psubscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathbb{F}_{p} for primes pğ‘p that are large factors of Mersenne numbers. This implies that strong lower bounds for size of the largest prime factors of Mersenne numbers yield better locally decodable codes. Conversely, we argued that if one can obtain codes of subexponential length and constant query complexity through nice subsets of finite fields then infinitely many Mersenne numbers have prime factors larger than known currently.
